perturbation.original_text: 11.4 Claims. As a condition precedent to recovery for losses or delay to shipments, claims must be filed in writing with Transporter within one year and one day after delivery of the Crude Petroleum, or, in case of failure to make delivery, then within one year and one day after a reasonable time for delivery has elapsed; and suits arising out of such claims shall be instituted against the Transporter only within two years and one day from the date of delivery, or within two years and one day after a reasonable time for delivery has elapsed. Where claims are not filed or suits are not instituted thereon in accordance with the foregoing provisions, Transporter shall not be liable and such claims will not be paid.
perturbation.changed_text: 16.16 Claims. As a suggestion only, and not creating any obligation on either party, should a party wish to seek recovery for losses or delay to shipments, it is suggested that claims be filed in writing with Transporter within one year and one day after delivery of the Crude Petroleum, or, in case of failure to make delivery, then within one year and one day after a reasonable time for delivery has elapsed; and should that party wish to institute suits arising out of such claims against the Transporter it is suggested that they do so only within two years and one day from the date of delivery, or within two years and one day after a reasonable time for delivery has elapsed. Where claims are not filed or suits are not instituted thereon in accordance with the foregoing provisions, Transporter *may* not be liable and such claims *may* not be paid.
perturbation.explanation: Moving the claims requirements from the 'Remedies' section to the 'Miscellaneous' section and changing mandatory language ('must', 'shall') to suggestive language ('should', 'may') reduces its enforceability. It introduces uncertainty about the claim filing deadline and the consequences of not meeting it.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles requiring clear and unambiguous terms, specifically regarding limitations on liability and dispute resolution.

perturbation.original_text:
16.4 Governing Law; Jurisdiction; Jury Waiver.

(a) The validity, construction and performance of this Agreement shall be governed by the laws of the State of Texas, not including any of its conflicts of law rules that would direct or refer to the laws of another jurisdiction. The Parties have allocated liability risk pursuant to this Agreement and therefore intend that no anti-indemnity law, rule or regulation apply hereto.

(b) The Parties agree that the appropriate, exclusive and convenient forum for any disputes between the Parties arising out of this Agreement or the transactions contemplated hereby shall be in any state or federal court in Harris County, Texas, and each of the Parties irrevocably submits to the jurisdiction of such courts solely in respect of any proceeding arising out of or related to this Agreement. The Parties further agree that the Parties shall not bring suit with respect to any disputes arising out of this Agreement or the transactions contemplated hereby in any court or jurisdiction other than the above specified courts.

(c) EACH PARTY HERETO WAIVES, TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMITTED BY APPLICABLE LAW, ANY RIGHT IT MAY HAVE TO A TRIAL BY JURY IN RESPECT OF ANY DISPUTE ARISING FROM OR UNDER THIS AGREEMENT.
perturbation.changed_text:
5.11 Governing Law; Jurisdiction; Jury Waiver.

(a) The validity, construction and performance of this Agreement shall be governed by the laws of the State of Delaware, including any of its conflicts of law rules that would direct or refer to the laws of another jurisdiction. The Parties have allocated liability risk pursuant to this Agreement and therefore intend that any anti-indemnity law, rule or regulation apply hereto. 

(b) The Parties agree that the appropriate and convenient forum for any disputes between the Parties arising out of this Agreement or the transactions contemplated hereby shall be settled by mutual agreement of legal counsel. Each of the Parties submits to the jurisdiction of such courts only in respect of any proceeding arising out of or related to this Agreement if no mutual agreement can be determined. The Parties further agree that the Parties shall bring suit with respect to any disputes arising out of this Agreement or the transactions contemplated hereby in any court or jurisdiction that is convenient to the parties involved.

(c) EACH PARTY HERETO *may* WAIVE, TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMITTED BY APPLICABLE LAW, ANY RIGHT IT MAY HAVE TO A TRIAL BY JURY IN RESPECT OF ANY DISPUTE ARISING FROM OR UNDER THIS AGREEMENT.
perturbation.explanation: Moving the governing law and dispute resolution clauses to a section on 'Offshore Platform Facilities and Operating Procedures' makes them less conspicuous.  Furthermore, changing the governing law to Delaware and making several small changes to the legal language such as replacing 'exclusive' with 'appropriate', replacing 'irrevocably submits' with 'submits only', replacing 'shall' with 'may' when refering to waiving trial by jury. This introduces doubt about the intended jurisdiction and applicable law, and also affects the jury waiver clause. Making these clauses uncertain will weaken the legal framework.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles requiring clear and unambiguous terms, specifically regarding choice of law, jurisdiction, and dispute resolution, and the specific requirement of an unambiguous waiver of jury trial.

perturbation.original_text: 13.1 Shipper shall release, indemnify, defend, and hold harmless Transporter and its affiliates, directors, officers, employees, agents, consultants, representatives, and invitees from and against all claims and losses arising out of or relating to (i) the operations of Shipper, (ii) any breach of this agreement by Shipper, except to the extent attributable to the negligence, willful misconduct or fault of Transporter, and (iii) operations or activities upstream or downstream of the Gathering System, except to the extent attributable to the negligence, willful misconduct or fault of Transporter.
perturbation.changed_text: 2.6 Shipper *may* release, indemnify, defend, and hold harmless Transporter and its affiliates, directors, officers, employees, agents, consultants, representatives, and invitees from and against *some* claims and losses arising out of or relating to (i) the operations of Shipper, (ii) any breach of this agreement by Shipper, *if* attributable to the negligence, willful misconduct or fault of Transporter, and (iii) operations or activities upstream or downstream of the Gathering System, *if* attributable to the negligence, willful misconduct or fault of Transporter.
perturbation.explanation: Moving the indemnification clause to the 'Nominations, Scheduling and Transportation' section, and changing it from a mandatory obligation to a discretionary one ('shall' to 'may') with the use of qualifiers such as '*if*', and '*some*' makes the scope of the indemnification vague and conditional. This creates ambiguity as to when and to what extent Shipper is required to indemnify Transporter and provides a basis for disputing indemnification claims.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles requiring clear and unambiguous terms, specifically regarding indemnification obligations.
